text: Number 492, Clarence Brandenburg, appellate versus Ohio.
Mr. Chief Justice, members of the Court.
There were guns?
There were guns in both films.
-- in both of them, wasn't it?
In both films.
Mr. Chief Justice and Honorable members of this Court.
And of all that would you see that is done.
I will never to follow through on the Court's request.
What was the size of this group of people?
With the Court's permission at the time of the marching around the cross, the size was approximately 10 to 20 as counsel for appellant has stated.
What is --
Prior to that --
Is there anything in the record that shows that more people were involved?
Yes, sir.
Was that before or after he says, he's going to bring 400,000 people to the district?
I'm sorry sir?
Was that before or after he says, he's going to bring all these thousand down to the District of --
That was just before that.
Anything else from the record to show that there was any possibility of -- in carrying out any of these?
Well, if Your Honor please.
With out country -- out in the country?
Well, but the broadcast was not in the country.

Except Mr. Kirschner the theory of the indictment as I read on page 2 of appendix is that these people were charged with violating the statute by what they did at that farm on two-mile road on that evening not with anything to do with the television broadcast.
Well, as a part --
Have you tried the indictment?
No.
Part of his acts at the scene you say were saying things knowing that they would be filmed and broadcast --
That is correct Your Honor.
In view of the fact Your Honor of the amazing circumstance in my opinion that I did not get allowance into the Supreme Court of Ohio.
So they're probably here?
So, they are within the possession of the clerk here.
Have you any recollection whether the state raised the question of failure to object to the instructions as one reason that the issue should not be --
The state has, not until we appeared here, I think if I'm correct, never raise the question of failing to object.
Now, how do you interpret that judgment of the Supreme Court of Ohio?
May it please the Court.
I see.
The --
So, that that's to say then in your view that judgment should be --
Considered to (Voice Overlap).
-- read as a determination on the merits of the constitutional questions.
Now --
Its just boilerplate in the Supreme Court of Ohio, isn't it?
That's boilerplate form when you're just turning it away on the merits of the substantive constitutional question.
You mentioned in your brief I think Mr. Brown that the reason there was no opinion in the Court of Appeals of Ohio was that the judge assigned to write the opinion died.
Judge Holman and you know him.
Yes.
No.
I see.
Either it would not appear in official record in it.
Was this a Kassay case back in 1932 the one that Judge Florence Allen wrote quite a eloquent dissenting, do you happen to remember?
I don't -- I don't remember a dissent at all.
I don't -- perhaps, I'm thinking about different case.
In Ohio, does everybody know who's been assigned to the opinion to write?
No.
What was the sentence in this case?
The sentence was 1 to 10 years --
On each count?
On each count for $1,000.00 fine.
And concurrent?
Concurrent, yes.
So that the --
So, this man could potentially for this act of stupidity served under the laws of Ohio up to 20 -- oh, no 10 years maximum.
Well, on your case you don't have to demonstrate that it says stupidity, do you?
No.
Mr. Brown, before we conclude I just like to say to you that the Court appreciates your acceptance of our assignment to represent this indigent defendant.
I should perhaps state for sake of the record that counsel for the appellant in no way agrees with any of the appellant's positions.
Thank you.
Thank you, sir.
We'll adjourn.
